questions.question_text:
A customer wants to securely deliver applications. They have given these requirements to an architect:
✑ 1,100 corporate users
✑ Applications run on Windows
✑ Confidential data must remain inside the datacenter at all times
✑ Datacenter has a firewall separating it off from the corporate LAN
Security team policy will NOT allow a corporate LAN subnet through the firewall to a datacenter subnet (example: source 172.16.30.0 /24, destination 10.10.1.0
//IMG//

/24 would NOT be allowed)
✑ Security team policy does allow corporate LAN subnets to access specific datacenter IP addresses (example: source 172.16.30.0 /24, destination
10.10.1.100 /24 would be allowed)
✑ 50 of the 1,100 internal users work exclusively on tablets, some Android and some IOS devices
Which two recommendations can the architect propose? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: There is no Direct Client Connection mode, you can just disable/enable the Secure Gateway. Therefore C/D cannot be the answer. I will stick with A/B.

I will choose A,C. I focused on allowing only a single ip. So It needs Gateway Mode.
and I think it will be no firewall for internal users.

comments.content:
The question boils down to either using Secure Gateway Mode or Direct Client Connection. Secure Gateway proxies connections through Connection Servers that would have well-known IP addresses. Given the security limitations, this would suffice. Direct Client Connections wouldn't fit the security rules as we'd expect to use DHCP on the Horizon Agents.

A & B.

discussion.content: Not sure about this, definitely don't like the AC answer. Direct connect brings you directly to a Desktop, bypassing the Connection server so RDSH apps cannot use Direct connect. Another note is all the users are internal on Corporate LAN so I'm thinking CD but am not certain. Let's discuss?
